title: The most hideous question since "Flash on D or F?"

replies.body: Neither. It's "papery things that you sometimes trip over on the way to the nexus"

> [{quoted}](name=Final Spark Lux,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=W4B18A1e,comment-id=0004,timestamp=2017-08-26T14:46:16.093+0000)

> Technically it's both. It's a tower with a turret laser at the top. I'll tell you what it ISN'T though. 
> 
> It IS NOT
> I REPEAT NOT
> TURRENT
> THERE IS NO N IN TURRET
> please stay in school kids

Used to moderate a stream, saw a bunch of people saying turrent so I made it a banned phrase. That word tilts me
I still want to know where this misspelling came from

It comes from an odd bit of psycholinguistics.  Words ending with a short 'e' followed directly by a 't' are somewhat uncommon in the English language, but there are a number that end in a short 'e' followed by 'nt' that are in somewhat regular usage ('current' is a good example).  As a result of this, some people have a strong subconscious tendency to 'fix' words like turret that aren't 'normal', and will pronounce the non-existent 'n' in the ending syllable of the word.  One of the more ironic examples of this is found in the voiceovers for GLaDOS in Portal 2, although she usually does not clearly pronounce 'turret' one way or the other.  Interestingly, the same thing happens with other uncommon cases of a short 'e' followed immediately by a hard consonant, but this particular case is one of the only ones to become commonplace.
Thanks for this tid-bit of knowledge!

KNOWLEDGE IS POWER. 

+1 for maximum academic merit

Edit: The word 'turret' does have an almost 'incomplete' feeling off the tongue when you get to the end of it.

The same could be said about a lot of words English borrowed from foreign languages TBH ('turret' comes from the Old French 'tourette', which means 'little tower', which I find kind of ironic considering the original discussion).

Overall though, it's a great example of how what languages you know influences your subconscious thought processes.

NA server tends to have higher winrate with flash on D because they are very likely to flash by accident when they say "**f**k me i screwed up" if set up on **_F_**. And there's less likely reason to press D by accident during typing

KR server tends to have higher winrate with flash on F because they use the D key to type in "ㅇㅇ" (it's short for yes in korean internet language) to reply to others. And there's less likely reason to press F by accident during typing.
